definition:
The subset construction is a technique of turning a non-deterministic
automaton into a deterministic one, while keeping the accepting language
the same. This technique shows that an NDFA is no more powerful in terms
of word acceptance than a DFA.

We begin by looking at a semiautomaton $(S,\Sigma,\delta)$. The
transition function $\delta$ is a function from $S\times \Sigma$ to
$P(S)$, which maps a pair $(s,a)$ to a subset $\delta(s,a)$ of $S$.
Observe that $\delta$ can be extended to a function $\delta'$ from
$P(S)\times \Sigma$ to $P(S)$ by setting
$$\delta'(T,a):=\bigcup \lbrace \delta(t,a)\mid t\in T\rbrace$$ for any
subset $T$ of $S$ and $a\in \Sigma$. Note that
$\delta'(\varnothing,a)=\varnothing$. What we have just done is turning
a semiautomaton $(S,\Sigma,\delta)$ into a deterministic semiautomaton
$(S',\Sigma,\delta')$, where $S'=P(S)$, the powerset of $S$.

It is easy to see, by induction on the length of $u$, that
$\delta'(T,u)=\bigcup \lbrace \delta(t,u)\mid t\in T\rbrace$.

Next, given an NDFA $A=(S,\Sigma,\delta,I,F)$, we turn it into a DFA
$A':=(S',\Sigma,\delta',I',F')$ as follows:

-   $(S',\Sigma,\delta')$ is derived from $(S,\Sigma,\delta)$ by the
    construction above,

-   $I'=I$, and

-   $F'=\lbrace T\subseteq S\mid T\cap F\ne \varnothing\rbrace$.

Since $I'$ is an element of $S'=P(S)$, and $F'\subseteq S'$, $A'$ is a
well-defined DFA.

$L(A)=L(A')$.

$u\in L(A)$ iff $\delta(q,u)\cap F\ne \varnothing$ (where $q\in I$) iff
$\delta'(I,u) \in F'$ iff $u\in L(A')$.

What happens if the NDFA in question contains ? Suppose
$p\stackrel{\epsilon}{\rightarrow} q$ is an $\epsilon$-transition, and
$p\ne q$. Then
$\delta'(\lbrace p \rbrace,\epsilon) = \lbrace q\rbrace \ne \lbrace p\rbrace$,
which is not allowed in a DFA.

To get around this difficulty, we make a small modification on $A'$.
First, define, for any $T\subseteq S$, the *$\epsilon$-closure*
$C_{\epsilon}(T)$ of $T$ as the set
$$C_{\epsilon}(T):=\lbrace t \mid t \in \delta'(T,\epsilon^k), k\ge 0 \rbrace$$
For any $T\subseteq S$, $\delta'(C_{\epsilon}(T),a)=C_{\epsilon}(T)$. If
the automaton does not contain any $\epsilon$-transitions, then
$C_{\epsilon}(T)=T$.

Now, let NDFA $A$ be an , define $A'':=(S',\Sigma,\delta'',I'',F'')$ as
follows:

-   $S'=P(S)$,

-   $\delta''(T,a)= \delta'(C_{\epsilon}(T),a)$, where $\delta'$ is
    defined in (1) above,

-   $I''=C_{\epsilon}(I)$, and

-   $F''=\lbrace T\subseteq S\mid C_{\epsilon}(T)\cap F\ne \varnothing\rbrace$.

By definition, $A''$ is a DFA, and it can be shown that $L(A'')=L(A)$.
The proof is very similar to the one given .
